channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Singapore Home Sales Fall for Second Month as Demand Weakens
item.description: Singapore private home sales fell for a second month as demand for new projects dimmed at a time when trade tensions are fueling unease about the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Dexter Low

item.title: Xero CEO on FY Results, Business Strategy
item.description: Sukhinder Singh Cassidy, CEO at Xero, discusses the company's full-year results and outlook for its business strategy. She speaks with Haidi Stroud-Watts and Avril Hong on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Uganda Using 'Extraordinary Measures' to Grow FX Reserves, Central Bank Governor Says
item.description: Bank of Uganda Governor Governor Michael Atingi-Ego says the central bank has taken "extraordinary measures" to grow the nation's foreign exchange reserves, including buying $1.5 billion from the market this fiscal year and using currency swaps. The transactions have so far amounted to $400 million, Atingi-Ego said from the capital, Kampala, in an interview with Bloomberg's Jennifer Zabasajja. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trade Chiefs Vie for Time With Greer at APEC Meeting
item.description: Trade chiefs from some of major economies are vying for access to US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer at the APEC trade ministers’ meeting. Many are seeking talks with Greer to discuss tariffs affecting their economies and to try to mitigate the impact of Trump's trade policies. Stephen Engle reports from Jeju, South Korea. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Manhattan Rents at Record Highs Hint at More Increases to Come
item.description: Manhattan’s apartment market is heading into its most competitive months of the year with rents already at record highs. They’re only likely to continue rising through the summer.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Epstein

item.title: US-China Trade Clash Risks Making Europe Dumping Ground for Cheap Goods
item.description: China’s widening trade surplus with the European Union is fueling fresh concerns that the 27-nation bloc risks becoming a dumping ground for cheap goods in the volatile tariff confrontation between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, William Horobin

item.title: Asian Stocks Fall as Trade-Truce Rally Loses Steam: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks in Asia fell on Thursday for the first time in five sessions as the rally on Wall Street sparked by US-China trade talks showed signs of exhaustion.
item.dc:creator: Richard Henderson

media:content.media:description: Former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers praised US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent for getting China to agree to a 90-day pause on tariffs. He calls it a good thing for the US economy. He spoke on Bloomberg Television’s Wall Street Week with David Westin.

item.title: Taiwan Calms Concerns Over US Treasuries Exposure at State Banks
item.description: Taiwan said the latest review of US Treasuries positions at its state-backed banks and their internal risk-management measures have so far found no major issues.
item.dc:creator: Betty Hou

item.title: India’s Shapoorji Nears Record $3.4 Billion Private Credit Deal
item.description: Indian real estate and construction conglomerate Shapoorji Pallonji Group is aiming to sign a $3.4 billion private credit deal in coming hours that would be the country’s biggest ever, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Saikat Das, Nic Querolo

media:content.media:description: Residential and commercial buildings in Mumbai, India, on Monday, Feb. 19, 2024. India recorded its best year for home sales since 2008. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: US Sanctions Against Oil-Cargo Inspector Jolt Singapore Traders
item.description: Washington’s sanctioning of a Singapore-based oil-services company has sent ripples through the local trading community, while renewing a focus on the clandestine supply chain that moves Iranian oil to China.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Serene Cheong, Weilun Soon

item.title: Malaysia Asks Bangladesh to Withdraw Migrant Labor Probes
item.description: The Malaysian government has asked Bangladesh to review and withdraw “unsubstantiated allegations” of wrongdoing in labor migration between the two countries to improve Malaysia’s rating in an annual US report on human trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Anders Melin

media:content.media:description: Saeed KHAN (Photo by Saeed KHAN / AFP) (Photo by SAEED KHAN/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: SAEED KHAN/AFP

item.title: China’s Glut of Coal Locks Market in Vicious Cycle of Decline
item.description: Chinese coal prices remain locked in a downward spiral due to a persistent glut of the fuel, according to the country’s top industry group.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Kathy Chen

item.title: Australia’s A$1 Million-Plus Homes Reach Record, Cotality Says
item.description: More than a third of homes in Australia, one of the world’s most expensive property markets, are now valued at A$1 million ($643,850) or more, according to research by consultancy Cotality.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings along Sydney Harbour in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. Australian capital city house prices continue to rise, and hotly anticipated interest rate cuts later this year could add further fuel to the fire, leaving some buyers and renters struggling to keep roofs over their heads.

item.title: Bangladesh Removes Restrictions in Currency Movement on IMF Push
item.description: Bangladesh has repealed an order that limited movements in its currency as it boosts efforts to adopt a market-determined exchange rate.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

item.title: Investors Expecting More China Stimulus, HSBC's Neumann Says
item.description: HSBC's Frederic Neumann says investors are now expecting Beijing to step up stimulus efforts "to get a recovery in domestic demand." Neumann tells Bloomberg Television that Chinese policymakers "need to cut rates." He also shares his views on the US dollar. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Rakuten Group Shares Sink on Worse-Than-Expected Loss
item.description: Rakuten Group Inc. shares tumbled by the most in five weeks after the Japanese e-commerce firm reported a 19th straight quarterly loss.
item.dc:creator: Alice French

media:content.media:description: Signage for Rakuten Group Inc. displayed at the Rakuten Optimism event in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Aug. 1, 2024. The event will continue through Aug. 2. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Reliance Gets $2.9 Billion in Biggest India Loan Since 2023
item.description: Billionaire Mukesh Ambani-owned Reliance Industries has obtained a dual-currency borrowing of $2.9 billion-equivalent, according to people familiar with the matter, the largest offshore Indian loan in over a year.
item.dc:creator: Chien Mi Wong, Saikat Das

media:content.media:description: Mukesh Ambani Punit PARANJPE / AFP) (Photo by PUNIT PARANJPEPUNIT PARANJPE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Indian Metal Stocks Emerge as Beneficiary of Easing US-China Trade Tensions
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: Hengrui Pharma Seeks Up to $1.3 Billion in Hong Kong Listing
item.description: Jiangsu Hengrui Pharmaceuticals Co. has started taking investor orders for a Hong Kong listing that could raise as much as HK$9.9 billion ($1.3 billion), the latest significant deal to boost the financial hub’s share-sale recovery.
item.dc:creator: Dave Sebastian

item.title: Why Tencent Is Investing In AI Gaming
item.description: Tencent has reaffirmed a commitment to keep spending on developing AI - which may crimp profit growth in the short term. But by integrating the technology across a suite of products it hopes to reap longer-term revenue and improve gaming experience. Elinor Leung, Head of Asia Telecom and Internet Research at CLSA, speaks on Bloomberg's The Asia Trade. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Falls a Second Day as Iran Signals Openness to Nuclear Deal
item.description: Oil fell for a second day following a report Iran is willing to forgo nuclear weapons in a deal with the US in exchange for sanctions relief.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Oil storage containers in Midland, Texas, US, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. Oil steadied following its biggest one-day jump in almost a year as fears that Israel may decide to strike Iranian crude facilities in retaliation for a missile barrage kept the market on edge.

item.title: Starbucks Is Said to Start Process to Revamp Vast China Business
item.description: Starbucks Corp. has contacted private equity firms, technology companies and others as it considers options for its China business, including a possible stake sale, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Dong Cao, Manuel Baigorri, Pei Li

item.title: Hong Kong’s Top Developer Sells Out Homes in Hours as Rates Fall
item.description: Hong Kong’s biggest property developer Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. sold out the first batch of homes for a new project within hours, as the lowest mortgage rates in more than two years lured buyers.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Kwan

item.title: China’s Investors Signal Trade Truce Is No Panacea for Markets
item.description: The trade truce is not enough to ignite a rush into Chinese financial assets amid expectations of reduced policy stimulus and lingering uncertainty on a final deal.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng, Iris Ouyang

item.title: China’s Riskier Short-Term Corporate Bond Spreads Hit Record Low
item.description: The Chinese central bank’s latest monetary easing has triggered a fresh rally in local corporate bonds, sending risk premiums to a record low as investors ramped up leveraged bets.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Qingqi She, Shuqin Ding

item.title: Philippine Bonds Ripe for Rally as More Rate Cuts Look Likely
item.description: Philippine sovereign bonds may rally in the coming months as slowing growth and easing inflation boost the case for further interest-rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani, Malavika Kaur Makol

item.title: Hong Kong Investment Banking Jobs Show Signs of Picking Up
item.description: Hong Kong’s investment banking job market is showing signs of a recovery, with the number of licensed professionals in the financial hub ticking up as initial public offerings have staged a rebound.
item.dc:creator: Cathy Chan

item.title: Gold Holds Drop as Fed Rate-Cut Bets Soften, Haven Demand Ebbs
item.description: Gold steadied after falling more than 2% Wednesday on signs there will be fewer Federal Reserve rate cuts than previously anticipated, and as easing US-China tensions sapped haven demand.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

media:content.media:description: An employee handles one kilogram gold bullion at the YLG Bullion International Co. headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, Dec. 22, 2023. Gold headed for a weekly gain after US price data came in cooler than forecast, reinforcing expectations for multiple interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve next year. Photographer: Chalinee Thirasupa/Bloomberg

item.title: Rich Japanese Still Fear a Yen Crash, UBS Wealth Manager Says
item.description: Speculators and much of the investing world have turned optimistic on the yen as Trump’s trade war keeps markets on edge. But there’s one key holdout that isn’t ready for bullishness: Japan’s richest citizens, worried about the economic outlook, according to a global wealth manager.
item.dc:creator: Bailey Lipschultz

item.title: Steve Cohen Says Probability of US Recession Now Stands at 45%
item.description: Billionaire Steve Cohen said the chance of a recession in the US now stands at about 45%.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Burton
